content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

Here is an implementation of the problem in Julia using regular expressions:

```julia
using RegularExpressions # Import regular expression package

function q_and_a_extractor(md)
    pattern = r"(?<=\n)\# (Question|Answer)(.*?)(?=\n\# (Question|Answer))"s # Pattern to match sections
    matches = collect(eachmatch(pattern, md)) # Find all matching sections in markdown
    
    if isempty(matches) 
        return ("", "") # Return empty strings if no matches found
    end
    
    questions = "" # Initialize question string
    answers = ""   # Initialize answer string
    for m in matches
        section, text = split(m.match, "\n") # Split match into section and text
        if section == "# Question"
            questions *= replace(text, r"\s*" => "") # Add question to question string after stripping leading spaces
        elseif section == "# Answer"
            answers *= replace(text, r"\s*" => "")   # Add answer to answer string after stripping leading spaces
        end
    end
    return (questions, answers) # Return the question and the answer as a tuple
end
```
This function `q_and_a_extractor` uses regular expressions to match sections of text enclosed between `# Question` and `# Answer`. It then strips any leading spaces or newlines from each section before concatenating them into strings for the questions and answers, respectively. If no matches are found in the markdown text, it returns an empty string for both question and answer.
